conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on hemispheres A and B and determine the coefficient of friction between hemisphere A and the left wall.
Hemisphere B has a mass 2m and is smooth, so no friction acts on it. Hemisphere A has a mass m and is in contact with the left wall, where friction exists.

premise: Hemisphere B has a mass 2m and is smooth.
conclusion: Vertical force due to gravity on B is 2mg.

premise: Hemisphere A exerts a force F on B at an angle of 30° from the horizontal.
conclusion: Force F exerted by hemisphere A on B has horizontal and vertical components.

premise: Force F exerted by hemisphere A on B at an angle of 30°.
conclusion: Horizontal component: F cos(30°), Vertical component: F sin(30°).
F cos(30°) = Normal force from hemisphere A = F_N, F sin(30°) = 2mg.

premise: Forces on Hemisphere A: Vertical force due to gravity: mg, Normal force from the left wall: F_N.
conclusion: Frictional force F_f between hemisphere A and the left wall.

premise: Vertical component of the force exerted by hemisphere B on A must counteract the weight of hemisphere A.
Maximum static friction: F_f = μ F_N.
